subject: Fixing HostName and adding support for HostAddress
commit_message:
Fixing HostName and adding support for HostAddress

When config options in different projects use IPOpt as the opt's
type, it restricts operators to only IP addresses.
When the opt is set to HostnameOpt type, currently even an
incomplete or invalid IP passes as a valid hostname. Also, currently
HostnameOpt does not make sure that there is a presense of at least one
non-numeric character in the provided host name.

According to RFC 1123, (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1123),
a valid host name can never have the dotted-decimal form #.#.#.#,
since at least the highest-level component label will be alphabetic.

This patch fixes the existing Hostname Opt to abide by the stated RFC
and also adds a new opt type that would enable operators to provide
either a hostname or an IP and at the same time perform checks on
both IPOpt type and HostnameOpt type, by setting opt type to
"HostAddressOpt" type. This would ensure that an invalid IP does
not pass as a valid hostname and at the same time retains the rules
required to be followed for the validation of an acceptable hostname.

Change-Id: I77bdb64b7e6e56ce761d76696bc4448a9bd325eb
Closes-Bug: #1619044

subject: Bump cryptography to work with patched openssl
commit_message:
Bump cryptography to work with patched openssl

cryptography embeds some data structures and function signatures from
openssl in its source code. One of these changed in a recent openssl
security release. The result of this is that it is not possible to
build python-cryptography<1.2.3 against the latest security patch of
openssl. We're pinning it to 1.1.2 for liberty, which is affected.

subject: imagecache: Hold shared storage registry lock while running
commit_message:
imagecache: Hold shared storage registry lock while running

This addresses 3 races in image cache:

1. Absent any locking, if the clean job took a very long time to run,
   it was possible for multiple instances of the job to run
   concurrently on the same host. As the job uses global state, this
   will certainly break.

2. When using shared storage, it was possible for a compute host to be
   brought up and create an instance which uses an existing backing
   image before the image cache manager runs for the first time. As
   we only run register_storage_use when the image cache manager runs,
   this means another host running the image cache manager on the same
   storage will not be aware of our instance when choosing which
   images to reap.

3. When using shared storage, it was possible for the image cache
   manager to run concurrently on different hosts. This is complex to
   reason about, and almost certainly fraught with bugs.

(2) and (3) are likely both mitigated if not practically resolved by
change I376cc951. However, a clean lock makes this code much simpler
to reason about.

This does not make this code race free, because we still race with
instance create. Change I376cc951 significantly reduces, but does not
eliminate that race window.

Resolves-bug: #1620341

These changes enable the resize operation surrounding LVM backed
instances. If the resize operation is scheduled for the same compute,
then the lvresize command is used to resize the disk. If the resize

that end with "_resize". These LVM disks are the original instance disks

must be removed.

Avoid converting to unicode if not needed

In python3, str is already represents unicode data. The current code

subject: Default use_stderr to False
commit_message:
Default use_stderr to False

While defaulting use_stderr to True might be a useful development
default, it is not useful for operators. Operators using systemd,
upstart, or any of these kinds of services, will find that if they
specify --log-file they will have two copies of the same logs on their
disk:

- one in the service log (e.g., /var/log/upstart)
- one in the log file they specify with --log-file

Instead of operators having to disable stderr log in every
configuration, we should just default it to False here.

Closes-bug #1588051

subject: Use default domain context when listing multidomain users
commit_message:
Use default domain context when listing multidomain users

In Identity->Users, if multidomain support is enabled and no domain
context has been explicitly selected, attempting to list the users will
make Keystone return a 401 Unauthorized error, which in turn results
in Horizon assuming that the token expired and logging out the user.

Because it's not possible to distinguish that error from a legitimate
token expiry (it should probably be 403 Forbidden instead), I'm adding
a check before we call Keystone, and use the default domain for the
context if none was selected by the user.

In addition, all the tests assumed that no context is selected, and only
worked because they mocked the Keystone calls (real Keystone returns an
error in that case). So I had to make the tests use a default domain
instead.

helpful for avoiding workarounds whenever we need to collect some
information from multiple services, e.g.:

data:

    ceph_pools: ['admin', 'openstack']

  - firewall_rules:
      '20_def':
        dport: 8080
    ceph_pools: ['manila']

will get processed into:

{
    "ceph_pools": [
        "admin",
        "openstack",
        "manila"
    ],
    "firewall_rules": {
        "10_abc": {
            "dport": 80

subject: Document and test group membership constraints
commit_message:
Document and test group membership constraints

This patch tries to document and test the following invariant that
should apply for all groups in the environment:

    A group should have either child groups, or hosts, not both.

Tests are introduced to confirm and enforce this behavior, based on the
reported failing configuration.

A new function, _check_group_branches, is added which will detect a
failing scenario before code that uses it is executed. If a conflict is
found, a GroupConflict exception will be raised indicating why.

The _check_group_branches function was placed before the physical skel
loading because the problem occurs during that phase; placing this in
the _check_config_settings function would be checking after the error's
already been raised.

A note was also added to _parse_belongs_to to communicate it's implicit
dependence on state as checked by _check_group_branches.

subject: ovsdb: don't erase existing ovsdb managers
commit_message:
ovsdb: don't erase existing ovsdb managers

The current existing agent erases already set ovsdb managers
entries. In some use cases, cloud admin sets ovsdb managers.
eg, for SDN controllers or monitoring purpose. Neutron agent
shouldn't unconditionally erase the existing ovsdb managers.

This patch implements a new api add_manager (along with
get_manager and remove_manager) to the ovsdb api which will
allow us to configure a manager on a switch without overriding
the existing managers.

Closes-Bug: #1614766
Change-Id: Ibf9bd02fac3070d166546cac478ef984e4e43f28
Co-Authored-By: sridhargaddam <sgaddam@redhat.com>

subject: Don't compile OVS kernel modules for functional job
commit_message:
Don't compile OVS kernel modules for functional job

The only reason we need newer openvswitch is following fix [1] for
user-space part of openvswitch. This patch fixes our
test_install_flood_to_tun tests.

Current 2.6 branch has issues with ovsdb where connection with native
interface is getting lost and functional job gets stuck. To mitigate
that, this patch switches back to OVS 2.5.1 version for functional jobs,
compiling only user-space part as OVS 2.5.1 kernel modules are not
supported by Xenial.

Fullstack job remains running with 2.6 because the job needs OVS kernel patch
for local VXLAN tunneling.

[1] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/56de2148f626d559a199028952fdd13f301ca80a
